Sunday Evening
The Johns Hopkins Orchestra,
under the baton of Hugo Weisgall, will present its annual
Spring Concert on Homecoming
Sunday, May 12, at 4:00 p. m.
in Shriver Hall.
Mr. Osmar Steinwald, director
of the Student Music Program
said, "The attendance is expected to be good as it has been in
the past." He continued, "In
fact, it should be better this
year due to the fact that it is
being held on Homecoming Sunday and that this week-end is
the twenty-fifth reunion of the
Class of 1932." .
The program will consist of the
following selections: "Overture to
the Barber of Seville," by Rossini; "Village Music: Procession,
Nocturne and Square Dance," by
Douglas Moore, and "My Country, No. 2, the Maldan" by
Smetana. Following intermission,
the orchestra plans to present
Beethoven's Symphony No. 2 in
D Major, Opus 36.
"The concert has always been
successful in the past and I expect it will be this year, also,"
Steinwald added.

Professor Gives
Numerous Books
To JHU Library
Dr. William Kurrelmeyer, professor emeritus of German at
Johns Hopkins, has left' 4,000
books in German literature to
the University Library.
This is his seventh gift to the
Library in as many years, making a total of 25,000 volumes
donated from his personal library. Although still living, Dr.
Kurrelmeyer in his will stipulates
that his entire library be left to
the University. The majority of
his collection has already been
transferred.
German literature of the eighteenth and nineteenth centuries
composes the main part of Dr.
Kurrelmeyer's library.
Dr. Kurrelmeyer has taught at
Johns Hopkins for 44 years, and
received his A. B. in 1896 and
his Ph.D. in 1899 from the University, returning in 1900 from
a year's teaching at Franklin and
Marshall College to work at
Hopkins. He was head of the department from 1927 until his
retirement in 1944, a member of
numerous scholarly organizations
and an author of many articles
in his field. .

neglect the inimanities." He felt
that the graduate student, however, should specialize. Dr. Pauling added that undergraduate
research is good experience and
shows the student how knowledge is really obtained but that

Dr. William Kurrelmeyer, professor emeritus of German at
